thread.title: Hotels Bring Live Music in Unexpected Places
thread.title_full: Hotels Bring Live Music in Unexpected Places - The New York Times

author: Shivani Vora
title: Hotels Bring Live Music in Unexpected Places
text:
Music — either live or recorded — is a common feature at many hotels, but some properties are getting more creative by offering instrumentalists and singers in unexpected places.
The Cornelia Spa at the Surrey Hotel in New York City, for example, has a violinist playing classical music in the relaxation library of its spa on select dates throughout the year. The performer also takes requests.
The Amelia Island, Fla., Ritz-Carlton has two acoustic guitarists, Richard Stratton and Alex Affronti, playing on weekend evenings on its Club Level. Strumming by the fireplace, they sing pop songs from the 1970s and 1980s.
Few musicians know how to use Thailand’s ancient plucking instrument called a khim , and the Paresa Resort in Phuket has hired one of them to play traditional music on the main lawn with views of the Andaman Sea.
In the Jumeirah Carlton Tower in London, a harpist plays in the lobby, but instead of the expected classical music, she entertains her audience with hits from Beyoncé and other Billboard Top 100 artists.
